contextId.occurrenceNote: This can be stated in active form. Alternate translation: "no one wrung their hands for her" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

contextId.occurrenceNote: This can be stated in active form. Alternate translation: "no one can recognize them" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

The idea of things being turned over to others can be expressed with an active form. Since it is also understood in the second part of the sentence, those words can be repeated there. Alternate translation: "You have turned our inheritance over to strangers; you have turned our houses over to strangers" or "You have allowed strangers to take possession of our inheritance; you have allowed foreigners to take possession of our houses" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
contextId.glQuote: Our inheritance has been turned over to strangers; our houses to foreigners

contextId.occurrenceNote: This can be stated in active form. Alternate translation: "our enemies sell us our own wood" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.glQuote: we must pay silver to get our own wood

contextId.occurrenceNote: This can be stated in active form. Alternate translation: "Our enemies have raped the women ... and the virgins" or "Our enemies have violated the women ... and the virgins" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
This can be stated in active form. Alternate translation: "they have shown no honor to the elders" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.glQuote: no honor is shown to the elders
